questions.text: A 3-year-old child is brought to the emergency department after a sudden pull on their arm. The child is holding their right arm close to their body and refuses to move it. There is tenderness over the radial head but no swelling or deformity. What is the most likely arm position in this condition?
questions.explanation:
Pulled Elbow (also known as Nursemaid’s Elbow)

Age group

1-5 years (most common)

Mechanism of injury

A sudden jerk or pull on the arm when it is extended and pronated causes the radial head to slip out of the annular ligament (radial head subluxation).

Clinical presentation

The child holds the affected arm close to the body in a slightly flexed and pronated position, resisting movement, particularly supination.

X-ray

  • Diagnosis is usually clinical.
  • X-ray is unnecessary unless there is suspicion of other injuries.
    • It may appear normal
    • If visible, they can show subtle displacement of the radial head, with the possible elevation of the anterior fat pad or visibility of the posterior fat pad, indicating joint effusion.

Treatment

Reduction of the subluxation by supination and flexion or hyperpronation of the forearm typically results in immediate relief.

questions.text: Match the following epiphyseal centres with their respective ages based on their appearance. 1. Capitulum a. 4 years 2. Radial head b. 8 years 3. Medial epicondyle c. 2 years 4. Trochlea appears d. 6 years
questions.explanation:
Epiphyseal centers

Age of Appearance

Capitulum

2 years

Radial head

4 years

Medial epicondyle

6 years

Trochlea

8 years

Olecranon

10 years

Lateral epicondyle

12 years

questions.text: A 35-year-old male fell from a height of about 6 feet while carrying a heavy load, landing on his left side and bracing himself with his left arm. Upon examination, there is a visible deformity in the mid-forearm region, and the elbow is swollen. Given the X-ray findings, what is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Monteggia fracture

Site

Fracture of the proximal third of the ulna is accompanied by a radial head dislocation.

Cause

Fall on an outstretched hand

Mechanism

Complications

  • Nerve injury (Posterior Interosseous Nerve)
  • Malunion
  • Non-union
  • Cubitus valgus.
  • Radio ulnar synostosis (Type 4 Monteggia Fracture)
  • Myositis Ossificans.

questions.text: A 22-year-old playing rugby fell awkwardly after being tackled, landing on his outstretched left arm, and experienced immediate pain in his forearm and elbow. He arrives at the emergency department with intense pain and is unable to flex or extend his elbow. Based on the X-ray findings, which type of Bado's classification does this injury represent?
questions.explanation:
Bado’s Classification

Type

Description

Seen in

Image

Type I

(Extension Type)

(Option A)

  

Anterior dislocation of the radial head with anterior angulation.

Children (more common)

Type II

 

  

Posterior dislocation of the radial head with posterior angulation.

Adults (more common)

Type III

(Option C)

Lateral dislocation of the radial head

Exclusively in children

Type IV

(Option D)

Anterior dislocation of the radial head and fractures of both the radius and ulna occur at the same proximal level.

Exclusively in adults

questions.text: A 30-year-old female slipped while demonstrating an exercise in a fitness class, landing on her outstretched right arm. She arrives at the emergency department with severe pain in her right wrist and forearm. Upon examination, her wrist appears unstable. Based on the X-ray findings, which of the following statements is true regarding her condition?

options.label: D
options.text: Posterior interosseous nerve is commonly involved

questions.explanation:
Galeazzi fracture

Aetiology

  • It is more common in adults.
  • Three times more common than Monteggia fracture (Option C)

Mechanism

  • Fall on an outstretched hand (marked pronation of the forearm).
  • Direct blow on the dorsolateral side of the forearm

Clinical features

  • Prominence and tenderness at the distal end of the ulna (main feature).
  • Piano key sign: It is a deformity where the ulnar styloid moves up and down when pressure is applied, resembling a piano key. This movement indicates subluxation or dislocation of the joint.

X-ray

Reveals a fracture of the distal third of the radius and a dislocation of the distal radioulnar joint.

Treatment

Surgery is necessary (fracture of necessity) (Option A): ORIF with long plate and screw (treatment of choice).

 

Complications

  • Nerve injury
    • Ulnar nerve injury.
    • Anterior Interosseous nerve injury (Option D)
  • Entrapment of Extensor carpi ulnaris tendon (rare).

questions.text: Match the following images with their respective fractures: 1. Colles fracture a) 2. Smith fracture b) 3. Barton’s fracture c) 4. Chauffeur fracture d)
questions.explanation:
Fracture

Description

Colles fracture (Poutteau's fracture)
  • Located near the cortico-cancellous junction (about 2 cm from the distal articular surface) with dorsal displacement of the distal fragment
  • Fall on an outstretched hand in a pronated and dorsiflexed position.
  • ‘Dinner-fork’ deformity: Prominence on the back of the wrist and depression in front.
Smiths’ Fracture (Reverse Colles’)
  • Distal fragment shifts and tilts ventrally.
  • Fall on outstretched hand in a pronated and flexed hand.
  • Garden spade deformity: Prominent dorsal bulge and a flexed wrist position.

Barton’s Fracture
  • Intra-articular fracture of the distal radius, specifically involving the volar half that shears off and moves forward, carrying the carpus along with it.
  • This injury typically occurs due to falling on an outstretched hand (FOOSH injury) and is often associated with wrist instability and articular involvement.

Chauffeur’s Fracture (Radial Styloid Fracture, Hutchinson's Fracture, Backfire

Fracture)
  • Fracture of the radial styloid process of the distal radius.
  • It is caused by forced radial deviation of the wrist and may occur after a fall or when a starting handle ‘kicks back’.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the emergency department after falling while carrying a heavy load. Upon examination, he exhibits swelling, tenderness over the distal radius, and limited wrist motion. An X-ray is shown below. Which of the following statements about this condition is not true?

options.label: A
options.text: Fall on an outstretched hand with the wrist flexed

options.label: D
options.text: Involves volar displacement of the distal radius

questions.explanation:
Smith fracture or Reverse Colles fracture

Site

Involves the distal end of the radius with volar displacement of the distal fragment (opposite to a Colles fracture).(Option D)

Mechanism

It occurs due to a fall on an outstretched hand with a flexed wrist, leading to ventral displacement and tilting of the distal fragment. (Option A)

X-ray

Shows a tilted or displaced distal fragment at the radius.

Management

  • Closed reduction followed by above-elbow plaster of Paris (POP) immobilisation in extension for six weeks.
  • Open reduction using an Ellis plate (if closed reduction is unsuccessful).

Complications

Garden Spade Deformity: Characterized by a prominent dorsal bulge and a flexed wrist position. (Option B)


 

Type of Cast

Indication

Position/Purpose

Colles' Cast (Handshake Cast)

Colles' fracture (distal radius)

Palmar flexion,pronation and ulnar deviation (prevent dorsal displacement).

 

Scaphoid Cast (Glass Holding Cast)

Scaphoid fracture

Wrist in slight extension, radial deviation with thumb in opposition.

 

Ulnar Gutter Cast

Fractures of 4th and 5th metacarpals

Immobilises the wrist and fingers in a neutral/slightly flexed position.

Radial Gutter Cast

Fractures of 2nd and 3rd metacarpals

Immobilises wrist and fingers in a functional position.

Sarmiento Cast

Mid-shaft humerus fractures

Allows elbow movement while immobilising the humerus for functional healing.

Patellar Tendon Bearing (PTB) Cast

Tibial fractures

Allows partial weight-bearing without stressing the tibial fracture site.

Hip Spica Cast

Femoral fractures in children

Immobilises hip and leg for femoral and pelvic fracture stabilisation.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents to the emergency department after falling on an outstretched hand during a sports activity. He complains of pain and swelling in his wrist, with tenderness in the anatomical snuffbox. X-ray imaging reveals a fracture of a carpal bone. What is the most common site of this fracture, and which part is most at risk for avascular necrosis?
questions.explanation:
Scaphoid fracture

Site

  • Waist of scaphoid (most common) (Option D)
  • Distal pole (Least common)
  • Proximal pole (high risk for avascular necrosis)

Mechanism of injury

Typically caused by a fall on an outstretched hand (FOOSH) with the wrist in dorsiflexion.

Clinical features

  • It is more common in young adults, particularly athletes.
  • Pain and tenderness localised to the anatomical snuffbox (the depression between the tendons of the extensor pollicis longus and the abductor pollicis longus/extensor pollicis brevis).
  • Swelling and reduced range of motion at the wrist.

X-ray

There is a visible fracture line at the waist of the scaphoid, with possible cortical disruption or displacement; avascular necrosis may later appear as sclerosis in the proximal pole.

Management

Immobilisation by scaphoid cast (3-4 months)
 

Complications

  • Avascular necrosis (more common in the proximal pole) (Option D)
  • Humpback deformity (displaced Scaphoid fracture)
  • Delayed and non-union
  • Wrist osteoarthritis

questions.text: Match the following fractures with their site : 1. Mallet finger a) Comminuted fracture of base of the 1st metacarpal 2. Jersey's finger b) Neck of the 5th metacarpal 3. Rolando fracture c) Oblique fracture of base of the 1st metacarpal 4. Bennett fracture d) Rupture of the extensor tendon at the base of the distal phalanx 5. Boxer's fracture e) Rupture of distal end of flexor digitorum profundus of index finger
questions.explanation:
Fracture

Description

Image
Mallet finger (Baseball finger)
  • A sudden passive flexion of the distal interphalangeal joint (DIP) causes the extensor tendon at the base of the distal phalanx to be avulsed from its insertion.
  • Treatment: Immobilize the DIP joint (Aluminium splint or plaster cast).

Jersey's finger
  • It is caused by sudden hyperextension of the distal joint, leading to avulsion of the flexor digitorum profundus tendon. This injury may result in either a rupture of the tendon or the detachment of a small bone fragment.

 

 

Rolando fracture
  • A comminuted (3 parts) articular fracture (‘T' or 'Y' shaped) of the base of the first metacarpal.
  • Treatment: Reduction and fixation with K-wires, followed by immobilisation in a thumb spica for 3 weeks.

 

Bennett fracture
  • Oblique intra-articular fracture (2 part) of the base of the first metacarpal with subluxation of the metacarpal.
  • It is caused by a longitudinal force applied to the thumb.
  • Treatment:
    • Closed reduction and percutaneous K-wire fixation
    • Open reduction and internal fixation

 

 

Boxer's fracture
  • Fracture through the neck of the metacarpal (commonly the 5th metacarpal).
  • Cause: Closed fist hits against a hard object
  • Treatment: Mostly conservative

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents with severe wrist pain after falling while playing tennis. Upon examination, there is swelling and tenderness on the ulnar side of the wrist, along with difficulty gripping. An X-ray is taken. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Fracture of the Hamate

Site

  • Hook of the Hamate (most common site for fractures)
  • Body of the Hamate (less common, rare)

Mechanism of injury

Typically caused by a direct blow to the palm, such as from a poor golf swing or a fall onto the palm.

Clinical features

  • Pain localised to the medial side of the palm, often exacerbated by gripping.
  • Swelling and tenderness over the hook of the hamate.
  • Difficulty in gripping objects due to pain and limited range of motion.

Diagnosis
  • X-rays may show a fracture line in the hook of the hamate or body of the hamate.

 
  • CT scans or MRIs are useful for confirming the diagnosis and assessing complications, such as avascular necrosis.

Management

  • Immobilisation with a short arm cast for 4-6 weeks to allow for healing.
  • Excision of the hook of the hamate may be necessary in cases of nonunion or persistent symptoms.

Carpal bone

Age of Appearance

Capitate

2nd month

Hamate

3rd month (end)

Triquetral

3rd year

Lunate

4th year (females); 5th year (males)

Scaphoid

Trapezium

Trapezoid

Pisiform

12th year (females); 9th to 10th year (males)

questions.text: Which of the following combinations of fracture and commonly injured nerves are correctly matched? a) Monteggia fracture - Posterior Interosseous Nerve b) Shaft of humerus fracture - Radial nerve c) Supracondylar fracture - Anterior Interosseous Nerve d) Hook of Hamate fracture - Deep branch of ulnar nerve
questions.explanation:
Shoulder dislocation

Axillary nerve

Humeral shaft fracture

Radial nerve

Supracondylar Humerus fracture

Median (mainly Anterior Interosseous nerve)

Holstein–Lewis fracture

Radial nerve

Elbow medial condyle

Ulnar Nerve

Monteggia fracture

Posterior interosseous nerve

Hook of Hamate Fracture

Deep branch of Ulnar nerve

Lunate Dislocation

Median nerve

Hip dislocation

Sciatic nerve

Knee dislocation/Neck of Fibula Fracture

Peroneal nerve

questions.text: A 3-week-old infant is brought to the clinic with a noticeable head tilt, as shown in the image. On examination, a firm mass is palpated in the neck region over the sternocleidomastoid muscle. Which of the following statements about this condition is not true?

options.label: A
options.text: It is more common on the right side of the sternocleidomastoid.

options.label: B
options.text: The Head is tilted towards the same side as the affected muscle.

options.label: C
options.text: The mass is often localised near the clavicular attachment.

options.label: D
options.text: The mass typically attains maximum size by 1-2 years of age.

questions.correct_answer: D. The mass typically attains maximum size by 1-2 years of age.

questions.text: A 6-month-old child with a noticeable head tilt is found to have a mass over the sternocleidomastoid muscle. The clinician is considering potential secondary deformities that may develop due to the condition. Which of the following deformities is most commonly associated with the condition?

A 5-month-old child presents with a persistent head tilt to the right. The clinician suspects possible congenital torticollis and considers possible associated syndromes. Which of the following syndromes is least likely to be associated with congenital torticollis?

A 6-month-old infant is brought to the pediatric clinic with a noticeable head tilt to the left and a firm, palpable mass in the right sternocleidomastoid muscle. The parents report that the child favours turning the head to the left and seems uncomfortable. Which of the following management strategies is most appropriate for this child's condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Immediate surgical intervention to prevent secondary deformities

options.label: B
options.text: Regular stretching exercises and physical therapy

options.label: C
options.text: Observation alone, as it resolves spontaneously

options.label: D
options.text: Use of a cervical collar to restrict head movement

questions.correct_answer: B. Regular stretching exercises and physical therapy
